resources.string: View is a basic component that appears on the screen and can be used to interact with the user. The following are examples of the most commonly used derived components of View.

TextView is a basic user interface (UI) element that displays text to the user. It is one of the most basic and commonly used views in Android development. Below are some key points and examples related to TextView:

ImageView is an user interface (UI) component used to display images to the user. It can display images from various sources, such as drawable resources, files, or URLs. Here are some details and examples for working with ImageView:

Button is an user interface (UI) component that the user can tap to perform an action, such as submitting a form, navigating to another screen, or triggering some other event. Buttons are highly customizable and can include text, images, or a combination of both.

EditText is an user interface (UI) component that allows users to enter and edit text. It is commonly used in forms, search fields, and other areas where text input is required. EditText extends the TextView class, providing additional functionality for user input.

Spinner is an dropdown list that allows users to select an item from a set of options. It’s similar to a dropdown menu in HTML. Spinner is useful when you have a list of options that don’t take up much space on the screen.

CheckBox is an user interface (UI) component that allows users to select or deselect an option. It represents a two-state button that can be either checked or unchecked. CheckBox is commonly used in forms, settings screens, or anywhere multiple selections need to be made.

RadioButton is an user interface (UI) component that allows users to select one option from a set of mutually exclusive options. Typically, RadioButtons are used within a RadioGroup, which ensures that only one button in the group can be selected at a time.
Switch is a two-state toggle button that allows the user to choose between two options: ON and OFF. It’s commonly used in settings screens to enable or disable a particular feature.

SeekBar is an user interface (UI) element that allows users to select a value from a continuous range by sliding a thumb along a horizontal track. It\'s commonly used for adjusting settings like volume, brightness, or other values within a specific range.

ProgressBar is an user interface (UI) element that visualizes the progress of an operation or task. It can be displayed as a horizontal bar, a circular spinner, or even as an indeterminate indicator when the duration of the task is unknown. ProgressBar is commonly used for tasks like file downloads, installations, or loading screens.
